content: Sure! An example of a benthic species that prefers exposed intertidal areas is the barnacle. Barnacles are sessile crustaceans that attach themselves to rocks, shells, and other hard surfaces in the intertidal zone. They have a hard exoskeleton that protects them from predators and desiccation during low tide. Barnacles are found in great numbers in exposed rocky shores and wave-exposed areas. They are adapted to tolerate extreme changes in water temperature, salinity, and exposure to air and sunlight during low tide.
